comments.content:
You mean like a slab serif -- Memphis or something like that?   
   
Biggest serifs I know of were in 1960s San Francisco psychedelic poster lettering.   
   
Nothing like Bodoni or Waters though.

When I read your question I wasn't thinking about thick serifs, I was thinking thin and long. My suggestions are Carol Twombly's ['Charlemagne'](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017155211/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/charlemagne/), or Xavier Dupre's new one for Font Font called ['Angkoon'](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017155211/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/angkoon/)
You could also look at Ablefont. I can't find a showing for this but when I googled it I learned that it was used for Harry Potter. It's a variation on Charlemagne but less regular.

I know a typeface with such long serifs the [designer](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017155211/http:/lucasfonts.com/) had to [bend](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017155211/http:/lucasfonts.com/lucasfnt/punten/punten-.html)  
them inwards in order to make the characters fit next to each other. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131017155211im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)
